When your ICP furnace stops keeping your home warm, trust Sears Home Services to get it running again. Our experienced HVAC technicians are trained to repair ICP furnaces of all models and ages. Whether your system won’t start, runs constantly, or blows cool air, we’ll diagnose the problem quickly and make the right repair.

Expert ICP Furnace Repair Technicians
Sears Home Services technicians are factory-trained and certified to service all types of ICP gas furnaces. We use professional diagnostic tools to find the cause of the problem and fix it correctly the first time. Our technicians carry quality replacement parts for common repairs, including:

Igniter and flame sensor replacements
Blower motor and capacitor repairs
Control board and thermostat problems
Gas valve and burner issues
Limit switch and pressure switch failures

We’ll explain what’s wrong, show you your repair options, and get your ICP furnace working safely and efficiently again.

Fast, Reliable Furnace Service You Can Trust
ICP makes dependable furnaces—but even the best systems can break down over time. Sears Home Services is ready to help with:

Same-day and next-day repair appointments in most areas
Fully stocked service vans for faster repairs
Guaranteed work backed by the Sears name
Transparent pricing discussed with you before any work begins

We repair ICP high-efficiency furnaces, standard models, and older systems. Our goal is to restore your comfort quickly while helping your furnace run at peak efficiency.


When to Schedule ICP Furnace Repair
Call Sears Home Services for ICP furnace repair if you notice any of these issues:

Furnace won’t turn on
Air isn’t warm enough
System cycles on and off too often
Strange noises or burning smells
Higher than normal utility bills

Delaying service can lead to more expensive repairs—or a full furnace replacement. Our technicians can inspect your system, identify the problem, and recommend the best fix.

Schedule ICP Furnace Repair Today
Sears Home Services is your trusted choice for ICP furnace repair, maintenance, and installation. With decades of experience and a reputation for dependable service, we’re ready to keep your home comfortable year-round.
Call us at 1-802-552-4364 or schedule your ICP furnace repair appointment online today.

ICP Furnace Maintenance and Tune-Ups
Regular maintenance helps prevent unexpected breakdowns and extends the life of your ICP furnace. A Sears Home Services furnace tune-up includes:

Cleaning the burners and flame sensor
Checking the heat exchanger and safety controls
Testing airflow and electrical components
Verifying proper ignition and combustion

View this brief video to learn more about furnace maintenance and cleaning by Sears Home Services:

Schedule seasonal furnace maintenance before cold weather arrives to ensure your ICP furnace runs safely and efficiently all winter long.ICP Gas Furnace repair is quick and easyEASY SCHEDULINGBook online in less than a minute.DIAGNOSTIC FEEApply your diagnostic fee to the costs of repair.PROTECTION PLANSSave up to $150 on your repair if you enroll in a home warranty.Frequently Asked Questions about ICP Furnace RepairWhat types of ICP furnaces does Sears Home Services repair?Sears Home Services repairs all models and ages of ICP gas furnaces, including high-efficiency units, standard models, and older systems. Our technicians are factory-trained and certified to diagnose and fix all ICP furnaces, no matter how old your system is.What kinds of ICP furnace problems can your technicians fix?Our HVAC technicians handle a wide range of issues, including furnaces that won’t turn on, blow cool air, or cycle on and off too often. We commonly repair or replace igniters and flame sensors, blower motors and capacitors, control boards, thermostats, gas valves, burners, limit switches, and pressure switches. We’ll find the root cause of the problem and recommend the right repair.How quickly can I get my ICP furnace repaired by Sears Home Services?In most areas, Sears Home Services offers same-day and next-day ICP furnace repair appointments. Our service vans are fully stocked with common replacement parts, which helps us complete many repairs in a single visit and restore your heat as quickly as possible.Why should I schedule regular maintenance for my ICP furnace?Regular maintenance helps prevent unexpected breakdowns, improves efficiency, and can extend the life of your ICP furnace. A Sears Home Services furnace tune-up includes cleaning the burners and flame sensor, checking the heat exchanger and safety controls, testing airflow and electrical components, and verifying proper ignition and combustion. It ensures technicians understand refrigerant types, environmental impact, and proper handling techniques.What is a Compressor?A compressor is a mechanical device that increases the pressure of a gas by reducing its volume, essential in various systems including refrigerators, air conditioners, and HVAC units for cooling and refrigeration processes.What is a Condenser?A condenser is a component of HVAC and refrigeration systems, responsible for releasing absorbed heat from the refrigerant into the outside air or a water line, thus facilitating the cooling process.Additional possible ICP gas full_content.content: Frequently Asked Questions about ICP Furnace RepairWhat types of ICP furnaces does Sears Home Services repair?Sears Home Services repairs all models and ages of ICP gas furnaces, including high-efficiency units, standard models, and older systems. Our technicians are factory-trained and certified to diagnose and fix all ICP furnaces, no matter how old your system is.What kinds of ICP furnace problems can your technicians fix?Our HVAC technicians handle a wide range of issues, including furnaces that won’t turn on, blow cool air, or cycle on and off too often. We commonly repair or replace igniters and flame sensors, blower motors and capacitors, control boards, thermostats, gas valves, burners, limit switches, and pressure switches. We’ll find the root cause of the problem and recommend the right repair.How quickly can I get my ICP furnace repaired by Sears Home Services?In most areas, Sears Home Services offers same-day and next-day ICP furnace repair appointments. Our service vans are fully stocked with common replacement parts, which helps us complete many repairs in a single visit and restore your heat as quickly as possible.Why should I schedule regular maintenance for my ICP furnace?Regular maintenance helps prevent unexpected breakdowns, improves efficiency, and can extend the life of your ICP furnace. A Sears Home Services furnace tune-up includes cleaning the burners and flame sensor, checking the heat exchanger and safety controls, testing airflow and electrical components, and verifying proper ignition and combustion. Scheduling seasonal maintenance before cold weather arrives helps ensure your furnace runs safely and efficiently all winter.

full_content.content: Glossary TermsWhat is the drum of the washing machine?The drum is the core part of the washer that holds your laundry and enables the cleaning process through rotation, agitation, and rinsing.What is a 608 Certification?The 608 Certification, mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), is required for HVAC technicians to legally handle refrigerants. It ensures technicians understand refrigerant types, environmental impact, and proper handling techniques.What is a Compressor?A compressor is a mechanical device that increases the pressure of a gas by reducing its volume, essential in various systems including refrigerators, air conditioners, and HVAC units for cooling and refrigeration processes.What is a Condenser?A condenser is a component of HVAC and refrigeration systems, responsible for releasing absorbed heat from the refrigerant into the outside air or a water line, thus facilitating the cooling process.

self.__next_f.push([1,"## ICP Furnace Repair by Sears Home Services

When your ICP furnace stops keeping your home warm, trust **Sears Home Services** to get it running again. Our experienced HVAC technicians are trained to repair **ICP furnaces** of all models and ages. Whether your system won’t start, runs constantly, or blows cool air, we’ll diagnose the problem quickly and make the right repair.

---

### Expert ICP Furnace Repair Technicians

Sears Home Services technicians are factory-trained and certified to service all types of **ICP gas furnaces.** We use professional diagnostic tools to find the cause of the problem and fix it correctly the first time. Our technicians carry quality replacement parts for common repairs, including:

* Igniter and flame sensor replacements
* Blower motor and capacitor repairs
* Control board and thermostat problems
* Gas valve and burner issues
* Limit switch and pressure switch failures

We’ll explain what’s wrong, show you your repair options, and get your ICP furnace working safely and efficiently again.

---

### Fast, Reliable Furnace Service You Can Trust

ICP makes dependable furnaces—but even the best systems can break down over time. Sears Home Services is ready to help with:

* __Same-day and next-day repair appointments__ in most areas
* __Fully stocked service vans__ for faster repairs
* __Guaranteed work__ backed by the Sears name
* __Transparent pricing__ discussed with you before any work begins

We repair **ICP high-efficiency furnaces**, standard models, and older systems. Our goal is to restore your comfort quickly while helping your furnace run at peak efficiency.

---

![gas-furnace-professional-maintenance-service-image](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/hoPtM7qrIQLyk5ayatXBG/65d92b701df9d8ddd7a110b44d6a993d/professional-gas-furnace-maintenance-service-image.png)

### When to Schedule ICP Furnace Repair

Call **Sears Home Services** for ICP furnace repair if you notice any of these issues:

* Furnace won’t turn on
* Air isn’t warm enough
* System cycles on and off too often
* Strange noises or burning smells
* Higher than normal utility bills

Delaying service can lead to more expensive repairs—or a full furnace replacement. Our technicians can inspect your system, identify the problem, and recommend the best fix.

___

## Schedule ICP Furnace Repair Today

Sears Home Services is your trusted choice for **ICP furnace repair, maintenance, and installation.** With decades of experience and a reputation for dependable service, we’re ready to keep your home comfortable year-round.

Call us at __1-802-552-4364__ or schedule your ICP [furnace repair](/repair/hvac/gas-furnace-repair-service) appointment online today.

___

## ICP Furnace Maintenance and Tune-Ups

Regular maintenance helps prevent unexpected breakdowns and extends the life of your ICP furnace. A **Sears Home Services furnace tune-up** includes:

* Cleaning the burners and flame sensor
* Checking the heat exchanger and safety controls
* Testing airflow and electrical components
* Verifying proper ignition and combustion

View this brief video to learn more about furnace maintenance and cleaning by Sears Home Services:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/aEQxr3ygENM?rel=0" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Schedule seasonal [furnace maintenance](/maintain/heating-cooling-maintenance) before cold weather arrives to ensure your ICP furnace runs safely and efficiently all winter long.
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"In this article, we examine the different home exterior options, the types of vinyl siding available, how to choose the right vinyl siding for your home. You'll also learn about the average cost to expect for materials and installation.

---

## Vinyl Siding Cost by Type

### Vinyl Shake Siding

The cost of vinyl shake siding can vary significantly based on several factors, such as the brand, quality, style, location, and the size of the project.
On average, the cost of vinyl shake siding can range from $6 to $15 per square foot, including materials and installation. This cost may also vary depending on the complexity of the installation process, any additional features, and the contractor's labor charges.

### Insulated Vinyl Siding

You may choose siding with additional insulation, particularly if your house tends to be poorly insulated. 
The average cost of installing insulated vinyl siding can range from $5 to $16 per square foot. This price includes the cost of the insulated siding, labor, and other installation expenses. Keep in mind that these are just estimates, and the actual cost might be different in your specific area and depending on your particular project details.

### Board and Batten

Board and batten vinyl siding provides a bold look for cottage style homes. On average, the cost of board and batten vinyl siding can range from $5 to $10 per square foot for materials and installation. The average cost can vary depending on where you live and the details of your siding project.

### Clapboard Siding

Vinyl clapboard siding mimics the look of overlapping horizontal wood planks. This is one of the most popular types of vinyl siding. Clapboard vinyl siding typically costs between $5 and $12 per square foot to install. The actual cost to install clapboard siding on your home will depend on the type of siding that you choose, complexity of the installation process, any additional features, and the contractor's labor charges.

### Vertical Vinyl Siding

The cost of vertical vinyl siding can range from $3 to $9 per square foot for materials only. You’ll need to add the cost of siding installation by a local contractor to figure the total cost of your project.

### Vinyl Log Siding
Vinyl log siding is a type of exterior cladding for buildings that replicates the appearance of traditional log cabins or log homes. It’s designed to mimic the natural and rustic look of wood logs. The cost of this siding typically ranges from $5 to $10 per square foot. This estimate includes the cost of materials and labor. However, keep in mind that prices can vary significantly based on your location and the specific contractor you choose.

### Vinyl Stone Siding

Vinyl stone siding comes in panels or tiles that are manufactured to resemble various types of natural stones, such as limestone, slate, or river rock. The panels are molded or embossed with textures and patterns that replicate the look and feel of genuine stone.

The cost of installing vinyl stone siding varies according to the type of stone that you choose and the area that you live in. This type of siding typically costs between $7 and $15 per square foot to install including materials and labor.

### Vinyl Brick Siding

Vinyl brick siding is made from polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and is commonly used to cover and protect the exterior walls of homes. The cost of installing vinyl brick siding typically costs from $7 to $15 per square foot. The specific cost of covering your home with vinyl brick siding may vary based on your location and the cost of labor charged by local contractors.

---

## Factors to Consider When Calculating Vinyl Siding Cost

How much your vinyl siding will cost depends on many factors in addition to the particular quality of siding you choose. The total area of your home’s exterior will determine the amount of siding needed. If your home is irregularly shaped, this makes for a more challenging installation and can result in more scrap and man-hours.

If you are not doing the installation yourself, there are labor costs to consider. If you need to remove your old siding before installation, this will add to the total, as well.

The [cost of siding](https://www.homeadvisor.com/cost/siding/install-siding/) typically runs between $3 and $12 per square foot. You can approximate the exterior of your home as rectangles and triangles to estimate the total area. The area of any rectangular space is the base x height. The area of any triangular spaces is ½ base x height. The total area is the sum.

You can then multiply the total estimated area by the unit price to get the total cost of the siding. For example, if your home has an exterior area of 1,200 square feet, the total cost would be between $2 x 1,200 = $2,400 and $7 x 1,200 = $8,400.

But other materials you need to consider are nails, trim pieces, and so on. Soffits or fascia pieces may be anywhere from $1 and $20 per linear foot, depending on the material chosen. It’s also often a good idea to include 10% additional material, as this is often how much waste is produced by cutting pieces to the appropriate size.

---

## How to Reduce Vinyl Siding Costs

Here are some tips to help you lower the overall cost of your home siding replacement project.

* Start by researching different vinyl siding options and suppliers. Compare prices from multiple vendors to find the best deals and discounts.
* If you have the necessary skills and experience, consider installing the vinyl siding yourself. DIY installation can save you money on labor costs.
* Higher-grade vinyl siding may offer better durability and aesthetics, but it can also be more expensive. Opt for mid-grade or budget-friendly vinyl siding that meets your needs and budget.
* Vertical siding can be less expensive than traditional horizontal siding. Additionally, it can give your home a unique and modern look.
* Inquire about any energy efficiency rebates or incentives available for choosing certain vinyl siding options. These rebates can help offset the initial costs.
* If your budget is tight, explore financing options that offer low-interest rates or special deals on home improvement projects.

Local service providers often offer several favorable financing options to help you complete your vinyl siding installation affordably. Explore these options with a siding consultant in your area to begin your vinyl siding installation."])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## Deciphering Dryer Noises: The First Step on How to Fix a Noisy Dryer

Our trusty dryers are household essentials, but they do sometimes make strange and concerning noises. Learning to identify these sounds and their causes will put you on the fast track to fix your noisy dryer.

### The ABC's of Dryer Noises and What They Mean:

* __Squeaking or squealing:__ These sounds often indicate an issue with the dryer's belt or rollers, either from worn-out parts or lack of lubrication.
* __Thumping or banging:__ If your clothes dryer is making a loud noise like this, it could be due to an unbalanced load or loose components such as drum support rollers or the blower wheel.
* __Rattling or grinding: This might be caused by loose items in the dryer drum or by loose screws or deteriorated parts creating a dryer making grinding noise.

## Fixing Common Dryer Noises

Follow this expert advice to fix a noisy dryer. When you’re unable to repair the problem yourself, [schedule repair service](/repair/dryer-repair-service) and we’ll send a Sears Home Services technician to your home to fix your dryer.

### Squeaking or Squealing

Inspect the dryer belt and rollers for damage or wear. A worn idler pulley will also make a squealing noise so check that component for wear. Swap out any worn parts and lubricate the rollers if necessary.

Follow the steps in this DIY repair video to replace the drive belt in a common type of clothes dryer:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hnMOYWmaEfI" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Using the steps to disassemble the dryer in the above video will also give you access to the drum rollers and idler pulley.

### Thumping or Banging

Redistribute an unbalanced load evenly and tighten or replace any loose components. A thumping noise in your dryer can also be caused by a drum roller that is flat on one side because the dryer sat idle for a long period of time.

Follow the steps in this video to replace a bad drum support roller:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sdvltoSW5dE" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

### Rattling or Grinding Noise

Always check pockets for loose items before drying clothes to prevent these from causing noise. Tighten any loose screws and replace worn-out parts.

Grinding noise in a dryer can be caused by worn drum glide bearings. Follow the steps in one of the videos provided above to remove the drum and check the glide bearings for wear and replace them if necessary.

## Keep Your Dryer in Top Shape to Prevent it from Making Loud Noise

Regular upkeep can significantly reduce noise and improve your dryer's performance. Here's how to keep your dryer running smoothly and quietly:

* Always clean the lint screen after each use to prevent airflow restriction that can lead to noise. Regularly vacuum the lint trap housing and exhaust vent to prevent lint build-up.
* Examine components like belts, rollers, and bearings for signs of wear and tear, replacing them as needed. Follow the DIY procedures in our [Sears PartsDirect Dryer Repair Help]() section to replace worn parts or schedule repair service to have a Sears Home Services technician replace worn dryer parts.
* Lubricate moving parts like the motor bearings and pulleys with the manufacturer-recommended lubricant. Ensure the dryer is level and stable on the floor to prevent excessive vibrations and noise.

Regular professional maintenance will help you avoid dryer noise and other failures. [Schedule Sears Home Services Clean & Maintain Service](/maintain) for your laundry appliances yearly to keep them in top shape and running quietly. Annual professional maintenance will also help your appliances last longer.

Excessive noise from your dryer may come from worn rollers, a loose belt, or damaged blower wheels. This post provides tips on diagnosing and repairing each source of rattling or squeaking. If you notice rattles or thumps from your dishwasher’s spray arms or pump, Sears Home Services offers [who to call for dishwasher repair](https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/dishwasher-repair-service) for a quiet, efficient kitchen routine.

Strange rattles, hums, or squeals often come from broken belts, loose pulleys, or failing motor bearings. This blog suggests partial disassembly or minor lubrication for mild noise. If the sound grows louder or metal grinds appear, immediate attention is key. Let a [dryer mechanic near me](https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/dryer-repair-service) replace any failing part before the damage worsens.
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## Unraveling Garage Door Opener Codes

Decoding garage door opener codes like the Craftsman, Chamberlain or Liftmaster blinking light can be a tough nut to crack. These codes are designed to give an insight into potential problems. In this section, we will discuss how to interpret these codes and provide solutions for common error codes.

Codes can differ by the brand and model of your garage door opener. However, some codes are quite common. For instance, error code 1 typically signifies a safety sensor issue, while error code 2 hints at a problem with the wall control. See error codes for all of the different types of garage door openers in our helpful [Garage Door Opener Error Code Charts](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/diy/error-codes/garage-door-opener-repair/1234637). These helpful charts explain garage door opener error codes and provide helpful DIY advice for resolving problems causing the fault codes.

Decoding the garage opener light blinking often requires consulting the owner's manual specific to your garage door opener. The manual will guide you on what each flash pattern signifies. Typically, the error code will consist of a series of flashes – indicating the error code.

Once you've identified the error code, you can begin troubleshooting. Some error codes can be fixed without professional help, such as error code 3, which indicates a motor issue. In this case, you could check for obstructions in the garage door's path or ensure that the garage door is unlocked.

If the issue persists or involves more complicated error codes, it's advisable to seek professional assistance. Sears Home Services offers expert technicians specializing in garage door opener repairs, capable of diagnosing and rectifying the problem efficiently. [Schedule garage door opener service now](/repair/garage-door-opener-repair-service) if you need a Sears Home Services expert to diagnose and repair your garage door opener.

Here are the top 5 reasons your garage door opener signals error codes and how to troubleshoot the problems.

## Reason 1: Door Alignment Problems -- Keeping Your Garage Door Opener in Top Condition

Regular maintenance is a vital part of ensuring the smooth and efficient operation of your garage door opener. Routine cleaning and lubrication, inspecting and tightening electrical connections, and replacing worn parts are key to maintaining optimal performance.

Cleaning and lubricating the moving parts of your garage door opener with a silicone-based lubricant can reduce friction and ensure smooth operation. Moreover, inspecting and tightening electrical connections can prevent erratic operation or garage opener light blinking. Finally, worn-out components such as springs, belts, and chains should be replaced to maintain optimal functionality. If you're unsure about performing these tasks, consider seeking professional assistance.

Checking garage door travel is often an essential DIY troubleshooting step in resolving garage door opener problems that cause error codes. Follow the detailed steps in this helpful YouTube video to resolve travel problems with your garage door:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/giZuLTMIOzc" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

## Reason 2: Safety Sensor Problems -- Resolving Photo Sensor Issues

A common reason for the Liftmaster blinking light on your garage door opener could be photo sensor issues. Photo sensors, which detect obstacles to prevent accidents, are a crucial safety feature. When these sensors malfunction, they can trigger garage door opener codes and disrupt the operation of your garage door. The light blinks 10 times on many garage door openers to signify a problem with the safety sensors. View this helpful DIY YouTube video to resolve safety sensor alignment and failure issues with your garage door opener:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/D1-jABFaOLU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>  

To troubleshoot, start by cleaning and realigning the photo sensors. Next, check for any obstructions or blockages that might interfere with their operation. If the problem persists, consider resetting the photo sensor alignment as per your garage door opener's manual. If you're uncertain about performing these tasks, don't hesitate to contact a professional garage door technician for help.

## Reason 3: Wiring Failures -- Addressing Wiring Problems

Wiring issues could be another reason why your Liftmaster blinking light is flashing an error code. Addressing these problems can resolve the error and restore your garage door opener's functionality.

Common wiring issues include loose or disconnected wires, frayed or damaged wires, and short circuits. Inspecting the wiring connections, repairing or replacing damaged wires, and ensuring proper electrical connections can help eliminate garage opener light blinking and ensure the smooth operation of your garage door opener. Unplug the garage door opener motor unit and examine all wiring connections using the owner’s manual as a reference. However, if you're uncomfortable with this electrical work, [schedule garage door opener repair service](/repair/garage-door-opener-repair-service) and we’ll send a Sears Home Services technician to fix the problem.

## Reason 4:  Garage Door Opener Power Issues

A lack of power going to your garage door opener can sometimes be resolved by simply resetting the house circuit breaker for the garage door opener outlet. If that basic DIY troubleshooting step doesn’t work, follow the expert tips in our [Troubleshooting Power Issues in the Garage Door Opener: Your DIY Guide](/blog/troubleshooting-garage-door-opener-power-issues-diy-guide) article to fix the problem. 

If you’re not able to resolve a power problem yourself, schedule garage door opener repair service and we’ll send a Sears Home Services technician to your home to fix the failure.

## Reason 5: Logic Control Board Failures

The logic board in your garage door opener senses signals from the remotes and wall control top open and close the garage door. The logic control board also sends current to operate the motor that moves the door. When the logic board fails, the garage door opener may not sense remote or wall control signals or it may not send current to operate the drive motor to move the door. A service technician is often needed to diagnose and repair a logic control board failure. If you suspect a control board failure in your garage door opener, you’ll likely need to schedule service.

Sears Home Services is your best source for garage door opener troubleshooting and repair help. Trust our technicians to help you get your garage door opener working again when a failure occurs. We’ll also help you keep your garage door opener and garage door in top shape with expert advice and maintenance help. Trust Sears Home Services for all of your home’s repair, maintenance and improvement needs. We’re always here for you.
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"This article breaks down everything you need to know, starting with a crash course on the basics of wiring diagrams, followed by a deep dive into how to use these diagrams for appliance repair. Finally, we'll walk you through a step-by-step guide on reading wiring diagrams, so you're fully equipped to handle any repair challenge.

At Sears Home Services, we're passionate about empowering you to maintain and repair your appliances. So, without further ado, let's dive into the world of reading and using wiring diagrams for DIY appliance repair.

Reading a wiring diagram can feel overwhelming—like a foreign language. But you can learn and understand the basics of using a wiring diagram by studying the following 3 sections of wiring diagram training. Videos in each section will help you become an expert at using a wiring diagram in no time.

## 1. Decipher the Symbols Used in Wiring Diagrams

First, we’ll take a look at some of the most common symbols you’ll find in a wiring diagram and learn what they mean. 

* __Lines__. The lines are wires. They connect the symbols, which represent components of the appliance. Following the lines will help you determine, the cause of a failure and buy the right part to fix the problem. 

* __Switches__. Most appliances have switches. The symbol for a switch on a wiring diagram looks like this: \___/    ___ . The switch starts and stops current going to a circuit or component in the appliance.

* __Dots__. Dots on a wiring diagram signify wiring connections to switches and components.

Learn more about the basic symbols you’ll find on a wiring diagram (also called a wiring schematic) by viewing this short video.

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Gaz-8cGVMxE" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Many wiring diagrams have the symbols labeled, or they have a symbol key on the diagram to help you decipher the symbols.

Here are a few more examples of common symbols you’ll see on appliance wiring diagrams.

![Appliance wiring diagram symbols](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/2SwH0Mh0qLjYJpLtcPhbGx/54d782a318e0329cb73791962e37837d/Appliance_wiring_diagram_symbols.jpeg)

## 2. Learn How to Read a Wiring Diagram

Once you understand the symbols used, you can learn how to read a wiring diagram or schematic.

This video explains where to locate a wiring diagram for an appliance and how to read it.

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/EVPnlcUI05I" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Learning to trace wires through components on a wiring diagram will help you understand what’s keeping a part from working in your appliance.

## 3. Trace a Circuit to Diagnose an Alliance Failure

Electric current travels in a loop called a circuit. A wiring diagram shows a map of the wires that connect all of the circuits in an appliance. 

When a component fails, you can trace the circuit through that component to know what to physically check to diagnose the failure.

View this video to see an example of tracing a circuit and diagnosing a component failure in a refrigerator.

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/yUKSrh59v4Q" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

As shown in the video, you’ll need a [multimeter](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/product/2lghb1rknn-0092-207/id-utldm1) to check wiring and components in an appliance when diagnosing a failure. Our [How to use a multimeter to test electrical parts video](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/diy/article/how-to-use-a-multimeter-to-test-electrical-parts-video) shows you how.

![Multimeter for diagnosing appliance failures](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/225BIGjnHOmVDM3aJxAvOY/bf1019a27454ca0f563a44da2eeb539b/Multimeter_for_diagnosing_appliance_failures.png)

Accurately diagnosing a failure using a wiring diagram and multimeter will help you buy the right part so you can get the appliance working again. 

Circuits in appliances can be more complicated than the one shown in the above video, but you can use this basic method of tracing and testing a circuit to understand possible causes of failures in your appliances.
